item.title: Pokemon Go March 2025 Events: Raids, Spotlight Hours, Community Days, And More
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/pokemon-go-march-2025-events-raids-spotlight-hours-community-days-and-more/1100-6529806/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

A new season is about to begin in Pokemon Go, and the mobile game is kicking it off in a big way with a variety of new and returning events throughout March.

The new Might and Mastery season will mark the arrival of the legendary Pokemon Kubfu, which will appear as part of the season-long Special Research story beginning March 5. On top of that, the game will host two Community Days this month, as well as a Dynamax Raikou Max Battle Weekend and a Mega Absol Raid Day.

That's just the tip of the Bergmite for March's activities, with the Bug Out, Festival of Colors, and more also on the horizon over the next few weeks. You can see all of the biggest events happening in Pokemon Go this month below.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • March Raid Schedule
    • Max Battles
    • Five-star Raids
    • Mega Raids
    • Shadow Raids
  • March Spotlight Hours
  • Powerful Potential
    • Field Research Encounters
    • Raids
    • Max Battles
  • Fuecoco Community Day
  • Festival of Colors
  • Dynamax Raikou Max Battle Weekend
  • Catch Mastery: Archen
  • Deep Depths
  • Totodile Community Day Classic
  • Mega Absol Raid Day
  • Bug Out
  • Fuzzy Buddy Research Day

March Raid Schedule

Pokemon Go is refreshing its raid rotations once again beginning March 4.

The legendary birds Articuno, Zapdos, and Moltres will return to five-star raids in the first half of the month, with Tapu Koko and Heatran slated to follow later in March. Mega Raids, meanwhile, will feature Mega Lucario, Mega Swampert, and Mega Pinsir, and Shadow Regice will appear in special Shadow Raids every weekend.

A new selection of Dynamax Pokemon will also appear in Max Battles throughout the month, including Chansey, Machop, and Caterpie. You can see March's full Raid Schedule below:

Max Battles

March 4-10

  • Gastly
  • Beldum
  • Pidove
  • Darumaka
  • Sobble

March 10-17

  • Krabby
  • Beldum
  • Drilbur
  • Darumaka

March 17-24

  • Machop
  • Chansey
  • Scorbunny
  • Falinks

March 24-31

  • Charmander
  • Caterpie
  • Chansey
  • Pidove

Five-star Raids

March 4-13

  • Articuno
  • Zapdos
  • Moltres

March 13-22

  • Tapu Koko (w/Nature's Madness)

March 22-31

  • Heatran

Mega Raids

March 4-13

  • Mega Lucario

March 13-22

  • Mega Swampert

March 22-31

  • Mega Pinsir

Shadow Raids

Weekends in March

  • Shadow Regice

March Spotlight Hours

Pokemon Go is hosting more weekly Spotlight Hour events in March, with a new selection of featured Pokemon and bonuses to look forward to this month.

Every Tuesday evening from 6-7 PM local time, one particular species of Pokemon will be appearing in the wild more frequently, making this a good chance to fill out your Pokedex and stock up on candy. On top of that, you'll earn an extra bonus during that hour, such as double XP or Stardust for catching Pokemon.

You can see March's Spotlight Hour schedule below:

March 4

  • Featured Pokemon: Makuhita
  • Bonus: 2x transfer candy

March 11

  • Featured Pokemon: Roselia
  • Bonus: 2x evolution XP

March 18

  • Featured Pokemon: Shellder
  • Bonus: 2x catch Stardust

March 25

  • Featured Pokemon: Cutiefly
  • Bonus: 2x catch XP

Powerful Potential

Pokemon Go is kicking its new season off with a new event called Powerful Potential, which runs from March 5-10.

The event will mark the start of the Might and Mastery Special Research story, which will introduce the legendary Wushu Pokemon Kubfu to the game. In addition, you'll have your first chance to catch a shiny Charcadet during the event.

On top of the featured Pokemon, event-themed Timed and Field Research tasks will be available throughout the event, as will special Raid and Max Battle bosses.

Field Research Encounters

  • Alolan Raichu
  • Hisuian Typhlosion
  • Sableye
  • Gothita
  • Solosis
  • Sinistea

Raids

One-star

  • Gothita
  • Solosis
  • Sinistea

Three-star

  • Alolan Raichu
  • Hisuian Typhlosion
  • Sableye

Max Battles

One-star

  • Dynamax Grookey
  • Dynamax Scorbunny
  • Dynamax Sobble

Six-star

  • Gigantamax Venusaur
  • Gigantamax Charizard
  • Gigantamax Blastoise

Pokemon Go's first Community Day of the month takes place on March 8 and stars the fire-type croc Fuecoco.

From 2-5 PM local time, Fuecoco will be appearing much more frequently in the wild, and you'll have an increased chance of encountering a shiny Fuecoco. In addition, if you evolve Fuecoco's evolved form, Crocalor, into Skeledirge by March 15, it will learn the special Charged Attack Blast Burn upon evolving.

Along with the increased Fuecoco spawns, a few bonuses will be available throughout the event as well. Any Lure Modules or Incense you use will last for three hours, and you'll earn triple Stardust and double XP for catching Pokemon. The game will also offer special Timed and Field Research tasks to complete during the event.

Festival of Colors

The festivities continue with the return of the Festival of Colors event, which runs from March 13-17. More details will be announced closer to the event.

Dynamax Raikou Max Battle Weekend

Pokemon Go players will have a chance to add another Dynamax legendary Pokemon to their collection with a special Dynamax Raikou Max Battle Weekend scheduled for March 15-16.

Along with a chance to challenge Dynamax Raikou in five-star Max Battles, the event will offer a handful of bonuses. The Max Particle collection limit will be temporarily increased to 1,600, and Power Spots will refresh more frequently. You'll also get eight times the usual amount of Max Particles from Power Spots.

Catch Mastery: Archen

Pokemon Go is hosting another Catch Mastery event, this one starring the fossil Pokemon Archen. The event is scheduled to take place March 16 from 10 AM to 8 PM local time.

Deep Depths

Pokemon Go's Might and Mastery season continues with a new event called Deep Depths, which is slated to run March 19-24. Additional details about the event will be revealed later in March.

March's second Community Day event is slated for March 22, and it will be a Community Day Classic starring the water-type Pokemon Totodile.

Throughout the event, Totodile will be appearing in the wild much more frequently, and you'll have increased odds of encountering a shiny Totodile. Additionally, any Croconaw that you evolve into Feraligatr until March 29 will learn the Charged Attack Hydro Cannon.

On top of that, the game will offer event-themed Timed and Field Research tasks to complete, as well as a handful of bonuses. Lure Modules and Incense will remain active for three hours rather than their usual duration, and any eggs you place into Incubators will hatch at a quarter of the distance they normally require.

Mega Absol Raid Day

Mega Absol is the star of another special Raid Day event scheduled for March 23.

Bug Out

Pokemon Go's Bug Out returns March 26-30. The event traditionally revolves around bug-type Pokemon, but Niantic is keeping details about this year's celebration secret until later in the month.

Fuzzy Buddy Research Day

Pokemon Go is capping March off with a Fuzzy Buddy Research Day on March 29. More details will be announced closer to the event.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds - Tempered Monsters And Artian Weapons Guide
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/monster-hunter-wilds-tempered-monsters-artian-weapons/1100-6529749/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Tempered Monsters in Monster Hunter Wilds are the toughest of the bunch. Survivors of many battles, they pose the biggest threat once you've reached the endgame portion of the campaign. They also offer you with the best rewards possible, so you should definitely track them down. Our guide discusses how to eliminate these targets so you can craft high-end gear known as Artian Weapons.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • What are Artian Weapons and Tempered Monsters in Monster Hunter Wilds
    • How to track down Tempered Monsters
    • Tempered Monster materials
    • How to craft Artian Weapons

What are Artian Weapons and Tempered Monsters in Monster Hunter Wilds

Tempered Monsters and Artian Weapons become available once you've completed Chapter 4-3: Wyvern Sparks and Rose Thorns. Here's a quick summary:

  • Chapter 3-5: Monster Hunter is the conclusion of the story proper.
  • When you're done with the story, quests become more free-form. You simply need to take out targets and complete quests so you can continue to increase your Hunter Rank.
  • Upon reaching Hunter Rank 20, you're given the Wyvern Sparks and Rose Thorns mission, which takes you back to the Ruins of Wyveria.
  • This leads you to a battle against a Lala Barina that you're tracking, as well as a Guardian Fulgur Anjanath, the first Tempered Monster type that you encounter.

How to track down Tempered Monsters

The Monster Hunter Wilds Tempered Monsters offer the most difficult bouts in the game. These creatures are battle-hardened, as you can see by the scars and old wounds on their bodies. They're tougher compared to normal variants, so don't underestimate them.

If you plan on tracking down a Tempered Monster, you can do so by opening the world map biomes to see which ones are currently active in a particular location. You'll also notice that a blue glow/waypoint leads you to these targets, as opposed to the green-colored trails for other creatures or items.

Tempered Monster materials

The reason why you want to eliminate Tempered Monsters whenever you see them is because they grant the usual loot from their species, as well as endgame materials. These are used to craft Artian Weapons in Monster Hunter Wilds--i.e. rank 6, 7, and 8 (currently the highest tier in the game).

Once you've collected enough materials, talk to Gemma at your base and select the Forge Artian Weapons option. You'll notice some key differences here.

How to craft Artian Weapons

The process of crafting Artian Weapons is vastly different compared to Low Rank or High Rank armaments. This time, you need to select three parts to develop a viable combination. Here are a few reminders:

  • You may only select parts that have the same rarity--i.e. rank 6, 7, or 8.
  • Parts have an elemental property or a status ailment property.
  • If you pick two or more materials with the same properties, the weapon gains that effect. If all three materials have different properties, then the result will be a non-elemental gear piece.
  • Example: 2x Thunder and 1x Sleep results in a weapon with the Thunder element. However, if you pick 1x Thunder, 1x Sleep, and 1x Dragon, then the combination would yield a non-elemental result.

It's also worth noting that weapon categories require different part classifications:

  • Great Sword - Requires 2x blade and 1x tube.
  • Long Sword - Requires 1x blade and 2x tube.
  • Sword & Shield - Requires 1x blade, 1x tube, and 1x disc.
  • Dual Blades - Requires 2x blade and 1x disc.
  • Hammer - Requires 2x disc and 1x tube.
  • Hunting Horn - Requires 1x disc and 2x device.
  • Lance - Requires 1x blade and 2x disc.
  • Gunlance - Requires 2x disc and 1x device.
  • Switch Axe - Requires 2x blade and 1x device.
  • Charge Blade - Requires 1x blade, 1x disc, and 1x device.
  • Insect Glaive - Requires 1x blade, 1x tube, and 1x device.
  • Light Bowgun - Requires 1x tube and 2x device.
  • Heavy Bowgun - Requires 1x disc, 1x tube, and 1x device.
  • Bow - Requires 2x tube and 1x device.

That does it for our Monster Hunter Tempered Monsters and Artian Weapons guide. Once you've crafted a couple of these high-end armaments, keep eliminating tougher creatures so you can continue to increase your Hunter Rank.

Soon, rarer and more difficult Tempered Monsters will appear. Of course, this also means that you'll be able to create rank 7 and, eventually, rank 8 gear pieces.

Need more tips as you continue fighting deadly creatures and venture into lands unknown? We've got you covered in our Monster Hunter Wilds guides hub.

Jason Rodriguez on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
